0.0: Mishnah: There are four "beginnings of the year."
0.1: The first of Nissan is the beginning of the year for kings and holidays. The first of Elul is the beginning of the year for animal tithes.
0.2: Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon say
0.3: [animal tithes start] on the first of Tishrei.
0.4: The first of Tishrei is the beginning of the year for years, for the Sabbatical years, the Jubilees, for planting, and for vegetables.
0.5: The first of Shevat is the beginning of the year for trees, so says Beit Shammai. Beit Hillel says
0.7: Gemara: Of what halachic import is [the beginning of Nissan] for kings?
0.10: for it is taught [in a (Mishnah Sheviit 10:5)],
0.11: 'Debt documents that are predated [that is, the transaction truly happened later than the year of the king stated on the document] are invalid. Postdated, valid.'
0.13: A king that is appointed on the 29th of Adar, once the 1st of Nissan comes, it is counted for him as [if he had been king for] a year.
0.14: If he had only been appointed on the first of Nissan, we do not consider it a year [of kingship] for him until the next Nissan comes.
0.16: 'A king that is appointed on the 29th of Adar, once the 1st of Nissan comes, it is counted for him as [if he had been king for] a year.'

1.0: teaches us that Nissan is the beginning of the year for kings, and that one day of a year [can be] considered a [full] year.
1.1: [It was previously stated:] 'If he had only been appointed on the first of Nissan, we do not consider it a year [of kingship] for him until the next Nissan comes.'
1.3: No, it is necessary, for [the case if] they elected him in Adar [but he had not yet assumed the role of king].
1.5: 'Let them count it as 2 years [of kingship once the next Nissan passes].' It teaches us [that it only counts as one year].
1.7: If he dies in Adar, and another one succeeds him in Adar, the year is counted for this one and that one.
1.8: If he dies in Nissan, and another one succeeds him in Nissan, the year is counted for this one and that one.
1.9: If he dies in Adar, and another one succeeds him in Nissan, count the first one [that is, the year that Adar was in] for the first [king], and the second [that is, the year that Nissan was in] for the second [king].
1.11: 'If he dies in Adar, and another one succeeds him in Adar, the year is counted for this one and that one.'
1.14: 'We don't count a year for two.' It teaches us [that we do in this case].
1.15: [It was previously stated:] 'If he dies in Nissan, and another one succeeds him in Nissan, the year is counted for this one and that one.'
1.18: 'When we say that one day [can be] considered a [full] year, [that's only] at the end of the year. But at the beginning of the year, we do not say that.' It teaches us [that a day can be considered a year even if it is a day at the beginning of it.]
1.19: [It was previously stated:] 'If he dies in Adar, and another one succeeds him in Nissan, count the first for the first [king], and the second for the second [king].'
1.21: No, it is necessary, for [the case if] they elected him in Adar [but he had not yet assumed the role of king], and he is [to be] a king the son of the king.
1.23: 'Let them count it as 2 years [of kingship once the next Nissan passes].' It teaches us [that it only counts as one year]
1.25: How do we know that we only [start the] count for kings [years of rulership] from Nissan? As it says, (I Kings 6:1) "And it was in the 480th year from when the Israelites left the land of Egypt, in the 4th year, in the month of Ziv [Iyyar], the second month of Solomon's kingship over Israel." There is a connection between the kingship of Solomon and the exodus from Egypt.
1.26: Just like the exodus from Egypt is [counted by years starting] in Nissan, so too the kingship of Solomon [is counted] from Nissan.
1.27: But the exodus from Egypt itself, how do we know we [start] counting [years] from Nissan?
1.29: Don't think that, for it is written, (Numbers 33:38) "And Aaron the Kohen went up the mountain by the word of God, and he died there, in the 40th year since the Israelites had left the land of Egypt, on the 1st day of the 5th month." And it is written, (Deuteronomy 1:3) "And it was in the 40th year, on the first day of the the 11th month, Moses spoke..." From the fact that when it was in Av, it calls it the 40th year, and when it was in Shevat, it [continued to] call it the 40th year, it implies that Tishrei is not the beginning of the year.
1.30: That is good for that [verse in Numbers] that explicitly mentions the exodus from Egypt. But that [verse in Deuteronomy], from where [do we know] that it [counts] from the exodus from Egypt?

1.32: [No,] it is as Rav Pappa said:
1.33: 'A scriptural connection [exists between] "20th year" and "20th year".' Here as well, a scriptural connection [exists between] "40th year" [in Numbers] and "40th year" [in Deuteronomy]. Just like here is from the exodus from Egypt, so too here is from the exodus from Egypt.
1.34: And from where [do we know] that the episode of Av [in Deuteronomy] occurred first?

10.0: Mishnah: During four different times, the world is judged.
10.1: On Passover, regarding produce; on Shavuot, regarding the fruits of the trees; On New Year's [ie. 1 Tishrei], all of those who are in this world pass before Him like children of Maron, as it is said, "He who fashions their hearts at once; He who understands all their doings (Psalms 33:15)." And on Sukkot, we are judged regarding water.
10.3: .If we are speaking about the standing, ripe produce- then one can object "all these occurrences that have happened to it already, when where they judged?"
10.5: we are speaking about the produce that will be planted later this year.
10.6: Is this to say that this produce is judged only once?
10.7: But I will challenge you from a baraita:
10.8: "produce which was subjected to a natural disaster or a disturbance- if it happened before Pesach, it was judged during last years Pesach (before it was planted). If it happened after Pesach, it was judged this past Pesach (when it was already planted)
10.9: likewise, a person who is subjected to a natural disaster or a disturbance- if it happened before Yom Kippur, it was judged during last years Yom Kippur. If it happened after Yom Kippur, it was judged this past Yom Kippur"
10.11: we see from here (this beraita) that produce is judged twice.
10.13: Therefore, when one sees that his slow growing crop is prospering, let him quickly plant his fast growing crop, in order that it should have grown slightly before the next judgement.

11.1: A person is only judged on the basis of his actions at that specific time, as it says, "For God hath heard the voice of the lad where he is" (Genesis 21 17).

12.0: Both the sinners of Israel and the sinners of the nations of the world descend bodily to Gehinnom and be judged there for twelve months. After twelve months their bodies are consumed and their souls burnt and the wind scatters them under the feet of the righteous, as it says “And you shall crush the wicked, for they will be as ash under the soles of your feet…” (Malachi 3:21)
12.1: But the schismatics, the betrayers, the converts away from Judaism, heretics, deniers of Torah, deniers of the resurrection, those who separate from the community, those who ‘spread their terror in the land of the living,’ who sinned and made the masses sin like Yerovam ben Nevat and his fellows – these descend to Gehinnom and are judged there for all generations, as it says “And they shall go out and see the corpses of the people who rebelled against Me…” (Yeshayahu 66:24) Gehinnom will be consumed but they will never be consumed, as it says “…and their form will outlast the grave as his dwelling place (zevul).” (Tehillim 49:15)
12.2: Why so much? Because they laid their hands on the dwelling place (zevul), as it says ‘as his dwelling place’ and dwelling place only refers to the Holy Temple as it says “I have surely built You a house to dwell in…” (Melachim I 8:13) Of all these Chana said “Those who strive with the Lord will be broken…” (Shmuel I 2:10)
12.4: their faces will be black like the bottom of a pot.
12.6: with them are the most beautiful of the inhabitants of Mechuza, and they will be called ‘the children of Gehinnom’.

13.0: "God passed over his face and called":  Rabbi Yohanan said:
13.1: If the text itself did not say this, no one would be able to!  It teaches that the Holy Blessed One wrapped himself like a congregational leader and showed Moshe the sequence of prayer.
13.3: Every time that Israel sins, they should do this sequence before me and I will forgive them.
13.4: "YHVH, YHVH":  I am the One before a person sins and I am the One after a person sins and repents.
13.5: "Merciful and compassionate God":  Rav Yehudah said
13.6: It is covenant that the thirteen attributes always work (lit.: do not return empty), as it says (Exodus 34:10) "Behold, I make a covenant."
